entry.answer: A japa who lacks wisdom and prajna (insight) is said to end up in niraya (netherworld). entry.answer: A Brahmin who practiced japa with unwavering focus for a thousand years was directly seen by a deity (devi). The text states, "The deity, moved by compassion, honored him and offered him a boon" (सावित्र्युवाच ||...||). This highlights the power of sustained spiritual practice.

entry.answer: The Brahmin refused material gifts, stating his focus was on dharma, while Yudhishthira offered wealth. The Brahmin insisted, "I do not accept wealth, O king," emphasizing that japa's true reward is spiritual, not material (ब्राह्मण उवाच ||...||). Their exchange underscores the value of truth over worldly gains.
